Course Topics

Unit 1: Fundamentals of Chemistry

  • Chemistry as a central science
  • Scientific method and measurement
  • Classification of matter (elements, compounds, mixtures)
  • Atomic structure and periodic table trends
  • Significant figures and scientific notation

Unit 2: Chemical Bonding

  • Ionic and covalent bonding
  • Lewis structures and VSEPR theory
  • Molecular geometry and polarity
  • Intermolecular forces (hydrogen bonding, dipole-dipole, London dispersion)
  • Metallic bonding and properties

Unit 3: Chemical Reactions and Stoichiometry

  • Types of chemical reactions (synthesis, decomposition, etc.)
  • Balancing chemical equations
  • The mole concept and Avogadro's number
  • Stoichiometric calculations (mass-mass, mass-volume)
  • Limiting reactants and percent yield

Unit 4: States of Matter

  • Gas laws (Boyle's, Charles', Avogadro's, Ideal Gas Law)
  • Properties of liquids and solids
  • Phase changes and heating curves
  • Kinetic molecular theory
  • Real vs. ideal gases

Unit 5: Solutions

  • Types of solutions and solubility
  • Concentration units (molarity, molality, percent composition)
  • Colligative properties (boiling point elevation, freezing point depression)
  • Electrolytes vs. nonelectrolytes
  • Factors affecting solubility

Detailed Chemistry Notes

Atomic Structure

The atom consists of a nucleus containing protons and neutrons, surrounded by electrons in orbitals. The number of protons determines the atomic number and identifies the element.

Key points:

  • Protons: positive charge, mass ~1 amu
  • Neutrons: neutral charge, mass ~1 amu
  • Electrons: negative charge, negligible mass
  • Isotopes: atoms of same element with different neutron numbers

Periodic Table Trends

The periodic table organizes elements by increasing atomic number and reveals periodic trends in properties:

  • Atomic radius: decreases across a period, increases down a group
  • Ionization energy: increases across a period, decreases down a group
  • Electronegativity: increases across a period, decreases down a group
  • Metallic character: decreases across a period, increases down a group

Chemical Bonding

Chemical bonds form when atoms share or transfer electrons to achieve stable electron configurations:

  • Ionic bonds: electron transfer between metals and nonmetals
  • Covalent bonds: electron sharing between nonmetals
  • Metallic bonds: delocalized electrons in metal lattices

VSEPR theory predicts molecular shapes based on electron pair repulsion.
